reviewText: I'll never forget watching this movie when it first came out. I was just a few months shy of my 11th birthday. I grew up in Fort Worth, Texas in the 1950's, and westerns were my favorite movies. Anyway, I went into the theatre and everybody was sitting and talking, and then the lights were turned down and it got real quiet. Then, simultaneously with the opening scene, came this incredible sound of the title song. The beat to that song and the sound of Marty Robbins' voice were so captivating, everybody in the theatre began clapping to the beat. And I have to say this, too: the background tenors in that song were phenomenal! I will never forget sitting there listening to that FABULOUS song and everybody clapping to the beat.The movie itself, in my view, has got to be one of the most underrated movies of all time. It never got the recognition and the accolades it deserved. In my opinion, "The Hanging Tree" is a classic. As others have indicated, the scenery is majestic and beautiful, and serves as a powerful backdrop to the film's story. I wish I knew exactly what spot it was filmed at so I could try to zoom down on it with Google satellite. I read that it is 35 miles west of Yakima, WA, and also read that it's in the "Oak Creek Wildlife Area," and in the "Ahtanum and Nile Valleys." That's not what I call an exact spot. If anyone knows the coordinates... longitude & latitude... of where it was filmed, would you please post them. I would like to see if I could recognize any of the 1958 "Skull Creek" land features, admittedly difficult from an aerial perspective.I got the VHS of the movie here from Amazon. But I would like to add my voice to the chorus of others who want to know what it would take to get the movie put on DVD. I read that what's holding it back is that the rights to the movie are partly owned by Warner Brothers and partly by the estate of Gary Cooper. Couldn't someone negotiate a deal that would be suitable to both of them?Not having this movie on DVD and made digitally sharpened is sad beyond words.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Gary Cooper near the end of his career; George C. Scott at the very beginning of his(his first movie); join Karl Malden in 1959's "The Hanging Tree"; for the first time on region 1 DVD. Doc Joe Frail is a strong(but mentally challenged) doctor in 1873 Montana. Drifting from one gold camp to another, he winds up in Skull Creek, and saves a young thief from hanging. Doc Frail would just avoid the Hanging Tree himself later on. Then Doc saves Elizabeth, a pretty young woman from Switzerland, who survives a stagecoach hold-up that kills her father. They fall in love. Doc Frail partners-up with Big Frenchy on a gold-mining scheme. Their testy relationship ends in tragedy. Filmed on location near beautiful Yakima, Washington, "The Hanging Tree" sports some lively and some stagey dialogue, but it all comes together thanks to the talented Scott and Karl Malden. Gary Cooper looks tired; and lacks the energy he showed just the year before in the excellent "Man of the West". Two years later his life would be cut short from prostate and lung cancer. "The Hanging Tree" was a so-called "thinking-man's" western. It comes with a Max Steiner soundtrack, and a good song by Marty Robbins, all in unrestored(but acceptable) Technicolor. This Warner DVD is the first region 1 release, as a region 2 DVD, a VHS copy, and a spanish version, are all that's been available for years. Don't miss a few good scenes with hard-drinking hell-fire preacher George Grubb, played by George C. Scott. Doc Frail is a mysterious character. Something happened years ago with his brother and his wife. Doc Frail burned the house down...
summary: Bread Cast on the Waters will be returned....
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie, got very absorbed in it, and spoiled by it I reckon.  Though not usually a Gary Cooper fan simply because there ain't so many such westerns to discover, I found his character (and all others) in this movie completely compelling.  The alpine scenery and atmosphere were virtually breathable, the mountain creek waters cold and clean, the smoke from campfires burnt my eyes (or maybe it was pathos), gold fever was palpable (although in my opinion, initially well-mannered miners too quickly morphed into a vicious mob), and Cooper's gunman masquerading as a doctor to escape old hurt and blame sustains empathy for him throughout the story.  No slouch himself, Carl Malden as the evolving villain evokes cheers when FINALLY dispensed with after (again, in my opinion) having lurked too freely for too long.  If you appreciate old classics, stories about the west, or about the gold rush, you will enjoy this movie too.  And it's a must have for your Gary Cooper collection.

reviewText: I am very happy that The Hanging Tree has finally come out in DVD.  Perhaps more people will see it and realize what an excellent movie it is.  I consider it in a class with the best westerns ever made, including High Noon.Gary Cooper plays Doc Frail, a character living with his demons from the past that make him his own worst enemy.  He is a gunslinging doctor who can only make contact with other people if they are his patients.There are four other very excellent performances:  Maria Schell, in one of her few English language films as the "lost lady" who is healed by the Doc; Ben Piazza as a young man rescued and tormented by the Doc;  George C. Scott in his first movie role as a drunken faith healer who hates the Doc; and finally, in a bravura performance as a stupid selfish man whose only interests are gold, girls and booze, Karl Malden.  Malden's character, Frenchie, is an antagonist in the Greek classic sense, whose greed and envy drives the action:  an Iago withou without brains.Everything swirls around Doc Frail, the object of Frenchie's envy, a classic protagonist.  It all leads to a climax that is more surprising to Doc Frail than it is to the audience when it finally comes.Don't let my lit crit style put you off.  It is a very good movie with beautiful scenery and fascinating characters and a climax the reflects both best and the worst in humanity - and the best of westerns.

reviewText: "The Hanging Tree," is one of the 'greatest' western films to come out of Hollywood!! For years, it wasn't shown on Television, nor was it given the respect it deserved, by being placed on a 'restored DVD." It was only offered on VHS!! Now at last, it's presented on a restored DVD which is beautiful in its, majestic and awesome, State of Washington, location shoot!! It's known as being the last western, Gary Cooper starred in!! It also stars, the fabulous, Karl Malden and it included the first screen appearance of George C. Scott. (Patton) The film came out in nineteen fifty nine; Cooper passed away in nineteen sixty, at the age of sixty! Purchase this beautifully restored DVD, you won't regret it. I purchased this fantastic DVD on Amazon.
summary: "The Hanging Tree," One of the finest westerns ever!!

reviewText: This was one of my favorite Westerns from my child hood.  I saw it in the theatre on first release and never forgot it.  Rich color and the story is first class. Yes I like it better than High Noon which I have always thought was a little slow paced.  As a Quaker Grace Kelly's character was off the mark.  Maybe her roll is why it is so aclaimed.Hanging Tree on the other hand shows a fairly accurate depiction of a mountain gold mining town. For it's time texturally like McCabe & Mrs. Miller.  Karl Malden is, as always excelent.  There are some great analogies about greed and good & evil.  The hypocritical preacher who is self-righteous is on the mark.  Then there's the haunting title song which is in a class by itself.  I have a VHS copy and just can't wait for the Hollywood restored DVD version.  Hollywood execs you're missing the boat as usual and could be selling this gem.

reviewText: Engrossing, well acted, one of Cooper's best performances. This is an adult Western beautifully filmed and written. Alternately very violent, then very tender and touching.Insightful into human nature and psychology both individual and mob psychology.Carefully crafted so that you will need to look carefully to detect the fact Cooper was dying as he made this film. A masterful performance of underplaying as always, he is at his best here and gives a clinic on the arts of film acting and screen presence.You will enjoy watching this film more than once to notice new perspectives/ layers/ performances every time you watch it again.

reviewText: It amazes me that excellent films such as "The Hanging Tree" and Arthur Penn's "Four Friends" (to name but two) are NOT yet available on DVD -- esp. LONG before such crap as "My Mom's A Werewolf" (to name but one example), which is!!! Other commenters have already summarized the story well. "The Hanging Tree" is one of the very best and detail-memorable of the western genre -- esp. if one discounts the epic westerns. And it's certainly one of Cooper's very best "contemporary films (along with "High Noon" and "Friendly Persuasion"! Co-star Karl Malden is excellent as always; and this was the time I recall noticing George C. Scott on film, in a small but scenery chewing role. I've not seen this film in at least 10~15 years, sad to say, but I hope to again. MAKE A DVD OF THIS FILM!!! Perhaps if this was by MGM -- They've released a slew of classic westerns lately. -- and not Warner Bros.!? I don't know, but it's a GD shame!!!

reviewText: This psychological Western ranks as high as "High Noon", if not a little higher. It is truly a sublime work of art. The script, based on Dorothy M. Johnson's novel, is intelligently written by Wendall Mayes (Anatomy of Murder) & Hallstead Welles. Much of the movie is filmed in the beautiful Ahtanum and Nile Valleys, Yakima, Washington and director Delmer Davis shows a good eye for action and bold vistas. Shot in Technicolor and superbly acted by Gary Cooper, Maria Schell, Karl Malden and Ben Piazza, the film is artistically and visually stunning! A haunting title song by Jerry Livingston (nominated for Oscar) and dramatic music score by Max Steiner (Sergeant York, The Fountainhead) complement the unforgettable story.It is 1873, the Gold Trail, Montana. People from all walks of life are coming to small miners camp in hope to strike gold. Among them is Doctor Joe Frail. A complex man. A survivor of the ultimate betrayal that left him emotionally damaged. An excellent doctor, he heals everybody from just about everything, but is unable to mend his own broken heart. Instead, he resolves to never trust a woman again and changes his name from Temple to Frail. "It suits a man with frail hope"- he'd explain to a friend. Exceptionally kind, caring and compassionate, Joe Frail would do everything in his power to help his patients. And yet, he could be equally mean (but always fair) to his enemies and would lose his tamper quickly if somebody mentioned his past.Doctor Frail saves the life of a young thief named Rune. Rune is desperate, homeless man, who would've been hanged or would've died from his wound if Doctor Frail did not operate on him. Rune can't pay the doctor for his professional service and so, he becomes his bond servant. It's not an easy relationship. Naturally, Rune is reserved and it will take him some time to realise that in fact, Frail has given him a home, a job and a purpose-a new lease of life.A stagecoach is ambushed near town. All passengers are killed, only the driver and a young woman survive, but she gets lost in the wilderness. She is Elizabeth Mahler from Switzerland. The locals assemble a posse and after three days search they find her badly bruised, blinded, traumatized and semi-conscious. Doctor Frail decides to save her at all cost. He spends days and nights nursing her back to full health, aided only by Rune. Frail becomes her protector and later, a secret partner in her endeavors.Tender love blossoms between Elizabeth and the doctor. Love that he longs for and would die for, but could not accept. There is only one cure for the damage caused by ultimate betrayal and that is ultimate sacrifice!  Maria Schell is outstanding as the innocent young Elizabeth, who makes that ultimate sacrifice for the man she loves. Maria captured my heart with her natural beauty and her restrained and powerful performance.Gary Cooper is tremendous as Doctor Frail. He was born to play that part, it suits his caring nature. As always, he gets gracefully under the skin of his character and they become one. In 1959 Coop won "Golden Laurel Top Action Performance" for this Oscar-worthy portrayal.Karl Malden plays with chilling realism the local villain and attention-seeker Frenchy Plante. He was deservedly awarded 3rd place "Golden Laurel Top Male Supporting Performance".Please, don't be put off by the title. There is a lot of humanity and wisdom in this story and many tender moments to savor. Without giving much away, I'd like mention a scene that involves a little girl suffering from malnutrition. Doctor Frail checks her thoroughly and tells her parents that she is malnourished. He realises that they are struggling financially and suggests they take his cow to fatten the child on some milk.-"I can't pay for no cow"- says the embarrassed father.-"I loan it to you" - replies the doctor.-"How much we owe you?"- asks the mother.Doctor Frail asks the little girl to give him a kiss and tells the parents that he's been paid.There is drama, conflict, gunshots and a great fist-fight woven into the plot. All evolves to an explosive climax and leads to the most luminous and memorable finale of one of the greatest love stories ever told!I do not understand why this magnificent film is neglected. It's a must see for any Gary Cooper, Maria Schell and Karl Malden admirer and for the fans of fine art in general. Thankfully, it is obtainable on DVD from Amazon.fr (France) or Amazon.de (Germany). Both sites have help pages in English with very good guidance of how to order, pay, return an item e.t.c. To get the help page you click on "Aide" (top right corner) for Amazon.fr, and on "Hilfe" for Amazon.de(top right corner). Also, you can email them in English and they will reply promptly and are happy to help. Both French and German editions have the original audio in English and the print is pristine. The only inconvenience is that the DVD is region  2 and you will need multi-region player, but the film is worth it. It must not be forgotten and it is in our power to prevent this happening. May be someday we will see region 1 edition with some extras- the kind of treatment "The Hanging Tree" deserves. I wish so and I hope so.
summary: A NEGLECTED MASTERPIECE! THANKFULLY, IT IS AVAILABLE ON DVD.

reviewText: It appears impossible to write a review of "The Hanging Tree" without mentioning how difficult it is just to see it! This reviewer first attempted to see HT when it was released in 1959.  It was November 1 (All Saints Day) and Catholic school kids had a holiday. My friend and I were turned away by the Beacon theatre on Broadway because public schools were in session-they thought we were playing hookey! That was it until 50 years later, when I rented HT from the local library! HT is unavailable on DVD and a check of amazon availability shows very high prices for used VHS versions.  The proprietor of a local video store refuses to stock HT, claiming he will never recoup his investment.  All this chatter normally would not belong in a movie review but HT is a special situation. Those who persist will be rewarded with a superior classical western.  Gary Cooper is very credible as a frontier doctor running from a tragic past. He sets up shop in a Montana boom town. Some of Coop's neighbors are a bit on the nasty side, including a smarmy Karl Malden and a just plain weird George C. Scott.  GC secretly stakes a couple to a mining stake. When they discover Coop's charity-and then strike it rich-gratitude is tossed aside and "complications" develop. A good review won't divulge resolutions but the theme song by the late Marty Robbins faithfully follows the plot. HT features sharp direction from veteran helmer Delmer Daves ("The Badlanders", "3:10 to Yuma") and fine scenery from Washington State. This reviewer will join the chorus in hoping that an affordable, available DVD version of "The Hanging Tree" comes forth. One could nitpick that some of the mob scenes are a bit over the top and the 108 minute run time could have been cut to a more traditional 90. Those rants are minor and are here just for the record. A closing thought: Many releases were designed for a Big Screen; "The Hanging Tree" must have been quite an in-theatre spectacle back in 1959.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An ailing, reflective Gary Cooper as Doc Frail- not frail at all as gun-toting, fist fighting, compassionate physician running away to a wild gold digging town where the ultimate law is the hanging tree.  He's a man with a haunted past who can't seem to escape himself.  He saves a young, embittered, new found criminal and eventually a beautiful immigrant blinded by horrific fate.It's a great story(based on Dorothy M. Johnson's novel) with wonderful characters:  George C. Scott in his introductory role as a creepy, Bible spouting "healer"; Karl Malden as the lustful, evil slimeball is super; Maria Schell, stunning, spirited, vulnerable and naive, desperately trying to understand and get through to Frail. Cooper is at his most understated self- in pain but always ready to do the right thing.The scenery is rugged and earthy: the makeshift town, the mountains, forest, and craggy old tree really sets the mood.  Marty Robbins sings the catchy tune(nominated for an Oscar).  I like the film much better than "High Noon" which seemed a little too packaged, pristine and a bit political(?). "The Hanging Tree" flows with nonpretentious action and drama and romance and uncertainty, all wrapped up perfectly in down and dirty britches.Where's this movie?  Why no US DVD?  Unbelievable.  Big thumbs up for great filmiing, great actors, great story!  Hope you can find it somewhere reasonably priced.
summary: Best Western Ever and Darkly Romantic to Boot!

reviewText: Another forgotten gem, somewhat overlooked in 1958: Now neglected in this 2012 DVD release. Diminished picture and sound quality, but worth every viewing minute. That's how powerful the story-line is. A spiritual treatise on love's dominion over all things material.Cooper and Schell are quietly and deeply engaging, and Malden is diabolically magnificent. Character development is subtle and literate...what a rarety in contemporary movies. Cooper's tragic aura is perhaps underlaid by the fact that cancer (unbeknownst to him, perhaps)was inexorably gnawing on his health.You may visit this minor masterpiece often...and weep.

The sound and picture quality is outstanding since it came out of the Warner Brother's film vaults.  Enjoy!!

reviewText: Yes, I agree with the others who've written reviews here.  It's fascinating that so many recall seeing it decades ago (when we were all much younger) and have never forgotten it. Me neither.Two other neglected ("why has it taken so long to get it on DVD") western classics all of you might want to know about--if you don't already: two Gregory Peck westerns that are so far superior to hundreds of others more well-known pieces of ... well, anyway: Yellow Sky and The Stalking Moon.  Fabulous.But, the "neglected jewels" syndrome keeps reoccurring in contemporary times, too. During the last ten years,  there have been many great ones that did not get their due, for any number of reasons (lack of distribution and promotion; timing: up against flavour-of-the-month blockbusters; "Oh, just another western..." mentality.) A few I can name right away;Ron Howard's The Missing, with Tommy Lee Jones ($60 million budget; $40 million box-office).The Proposition, an uncompromising Australian entry; brutal but fascinating. Had limited North American screen-time.Ride With The Devil, the most realistic look (and feel)in the saga of Confederate raiders in Kansas. Alas, too thoughtful a period-piece to be up against Toy Story. The box office says it all: first weekend, Ride earned less than $50,000.  Toy Story: $57 million.Kevin Costner's Open Range, in which he co-stars with Robert Duvall.  Happily, in spite of Kostner's decision to spend $1 million to build an authentic town and a $40,000 road to get cast and crew to the isolated location not far from Calgary, AB, it ended up a world-wide box-office success. Despite this, few people seem to recall it the same way they recall the recent True Grit remake or Eastwood's Unforgiven.  These are the "quiet" westerns...
Title: N/A

reviewText: There was stars and superstars, and then there are the handful by whose success one may understand the nature of the movies' massive appeal to the public... One of these rare people was Gary Cooper, a forever reliable cowboy who remained the strong fairly silent, man of action...Cooper plays Doc Joe Frail, a frontier doctor running away from a personal tragedy... He now takes his Hippocratic oath with a little gambling and gunfighting in Skull Creek, a wild gold camp in the territory of Montana...Cooper saves an accused thief from a posse and, after healing the young Rune (Ben Piazza), they become friends... Next the Doc treats a young Swiss girl, Elizatbeth Mahler (Maria Schell), for shock and blindness suffered from exposure to the sun after a stage holdup...After succeeding in getting her sight back, Elizabeth was already in love with Frail... The doctor tries not to sound his feelings about her... Something was troubling his conscience deeply... He certainly hides a mysterious past...Frail aids Elizabeth in a grubstake and, with her partners Frenchy and Rune, she soon strikes it rich... Frenchy tries to force his attentions on Elizabeth, but just then Doc Frail rides up...Karl Malden is excellent as Frenchy, the hypocrite opportunistic, the person without scruples willing to make Elizabeth believes that he cares for her, and is after her love, not after her gold... Malden is very good as a supporting actor... He proved it in "The Gunfighter," with Gregory Peck, in "One-Eyed Jacks," with Marlon Brando, and in "Nevada Smith," with Steve McQueen...In his film debut, George C. Scott portrays the poisonous bible-punching drunk who incites and excites the whole town to carry Cooper to the hanging tree...Jerry Livingston's Title Song won an Academy Award Nomination...
summary: A fascinating Western of the Gold Rush wave!

reviewText: While this Gary Cooper gem is a must have classic, I would recomend waiting for a U.S. release. The DVD seems to have been copied from a video tape source, with just a passable picture and the sound has an annoying amount of noise present. Only buy this copy if you just can't wait and HAVE to have it. The five stars are for the story, not the copy.

reviewText: This last time I saw this film, which was probably 15 or 20 years ago, it was excellent!The scenery was breathtaking, and it was Gary Cooper in color!I remember reading it was George C. Scott's first film, too.Somebody has the rights to this film, and I guess they're holding out for big bucks.  So what.Does anyone think we'll pay $50 for a DVD?  Or $80 for an obsolete VHS?  C'mon, people!The Hanging Tree is a good story, the film was done well and it affords great entertainment.But, "whomever you are," if you wait long enough--no one will care.  If you wait another 15 or 20 years, not enough of us will be around who care.Can you imagine if there was a Rudolph Valentino film which had not been seen in 50 years?  There would be a short line at the Box Office for that one!

reviewText: I was first able to see this film on TV in 1990. I had heard about it for years, but had not seen it until then. After seeing it I had to have it for my personal collection. I tried to find the film on VHS. It was many years later that it was finally released to video.  I recomend this film to any one who wants to see an excellent story, with excellent actors, excellent music, excellent film work and something worth keeping and to share with friends. A film that can be watched over and over. I hope it will be released to DVD soon. I believe that DVD allows everyone to see early films exactly as they were viewed in the theater when first shown.

reviewText: Just saw this -- finally -- on TCM two weeks ago. Haven't erased it from my DVR. May not, ever. It's a film whose images and dramatic moments haven't left me. I keep coming back to it, to view a minute or two, then staying right to the end. Only problem, it's not letter-boxed, which I'm sure TCM would do if it could. The real film must be something to view. But dramatically, once again Cooper is able to convey, as he does in all his films after the late '40s, an existential weariness and pain. It works wonderfully well here. The supporting cast of villains -- Malden, Scott, John Dierkes (an evil Ryker from Shane), and even Virginia Gregg as a cold-hearted townswoman -- are fantastic. And Maria Schell is a heart-breaker. But then women do melt wonderfully into Cooper and always did -- Schell recalled for me the tragic Manya Novak played by Anna Sten in the 1935 "The Wedding Night," a very different kind of film with a much younger heroic figure. But when the figure is played by Cooper, women fall totally, no matter the cost, in convincing ways. He commands that power to make us believe their love.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I grew up during the last part of our love affair with the Western in the movies and on the idiot box. The first western I ever saw was a re-release of "High Noon" at a drive-in in Florida when I was 5 years old, and I was already watching cowboys in old movies on our first tv when "Gunsmoke" premiered in '55. So it's surprising that I had never seen this movie. I was aware of it, however, because I can remember a Saturday at the movies in '59 when the previews/coming attractions included the trailer for this movie. Fast forward to recently when, thanks to Netflix and other sources, I have been revisiting some of my favorites from long ago. IMDB I  came across "The Hanging Tree" on a list of Gary Cooper movies when I realized I had never seen it. It was not available on Netflix so I tried my old standby, Amazon and found it was about to be released finally and was only to happy to order it. Apparently the only copy of the negative had some damage and in a very few places that is evident in the transfer, but by and large this is a gorgeously filmed movie with some very good acting and a story worth your time. Gary Cooper is outstanding and Karl Malden is excellent as "Frenchie". Other than Ben Piazza all the actors produce fine performances. It's one of Coopers' last movies (he released 3 movies in 1959, plus did a cameo in one other; and his last movie was 1961's "The Naked Edge"), and I am glad I finally got to see it. An enjoyable movie and a great example of the genre. Well worth the price.
Title: N/A
